title.narrative: ACT Alliance- Global Programme on Gender Justice 2019-2023
ACT Alliance- Global programme on Gender Justice 2019-2023

description.narrative: By 2023, the expected impact is that ACT Alliance and its members have contributed to changed policy, practice, narratives and attitudes on gender justice in faith-communities, by positively affecting the commitment of churches and other FBOs within the Alliance, as well as their programming and their advocacy efforts to realise gender justice. To ensure that all members and partners are able to contribute towards this overall goal, the programme is aiming at securing four outcomes, during a four year period: 1. ACT Alliance members are committed to promote changes in policy, practice, attitudes and structural arrangements, towards a more gender just distribution of power 2. The programmatic work contributes to gender just societies 3. ACT Alliance is a global progressive force for gender justice contributing to the SDGs and connecting the dynamics of local-global-local initiatives 4. The programme providers’ capacity and quality of interventions are enhanced

Insatsen avser ett 44 MSEK-programstöd till ACT Alliance: s globala jämställdhetsprogram 2019–2023, genom strategin för Sveriges utvecklingssamarbete för global jämställdhet och kvinnors och flickors rättigheter 2018–2022. Den totala budgeten för programmet är 4 525 110 USD.
ACT Alliance är en trosbaserad aktör som representerar världens största nätverk av protestantiska och ortodoxa kyrkor. ACT Svenska kyrkan är medlem i ACT Alliance och har en aktiv roll i denna insats. Medlemmarna i ACT Alliance är associerade med Världsrådet för kyrkor eller det Lutherska världsförbundet. Cirka 70% av ACT Alliance-medlemmarna är nationella kyrkor eller trosbaserade kyrkorelaterade organisationer från Syd.
ACT Alliance är en nyckelaktör i arbetet för ökad global jämställdhet. De utmanar teologi som motverkar genusrättvisa och jämställdhet och mobiliserar religiösa ledare för jämställdhet. Genom att bidra till förändrade samhällsnormer, policyer och praxis kommer ACT Alliance att spela en viktig roll för uppnåendet av SDG 5 och den övergripande visionen om en jämställd och rättvis värld där människor har makt att fritt forma samhällen, trossamfund och sina egna liv.
År 2023 räknar programmet med att ha bidragit till förändrade policys, praxis, narrativ och attityder som leder till ökad genusrättvisa och jämställdhet inom trossamfund. Detta genom att uppmuntra och stödja progressiva krafter och engagemang inom alliansen, genom att öka antalet program för ett transformativt jämställdhetsarbete, samt genom påverkansarbete. Detta förväntas uppnås genom att: 1. Aktivera och mobilisera ACT Alliance-medlemmars åtaganden för att främja förändringar i attityder och strukturer för ökad genusrättvisa och jämställdhet. 2. Stödja ACT Alliance nationella samarbetsplattformar (forum) i utformningen och implementeringen av programmatiskt arbete för ökad jämställdhet. 3. Använda sin unika position och nätverk för att fungera som en global progressiv kraft för genusrättvisa och jämställdhet, bidra till de globala utvecklingsmålen samt koppla samman arbetet som sker på det nationell, regional och global nivå. 4. Stärka alliansmedlemmarnas kapacitet inom jämställdhet både på individ och institutionell nivå för att säkerställa ökad kvalité på de program som genomförs.
Sida bedömer att ACT Alliance som är en trosbaserad aktör med ett omfattande medlemsnätverk och som arbetar med både humanitärt bistånd, långsiktigt utvecklingssamarbete och påverkan, är en relevant samarbetspart till Sida och ser dess kompletterande roll till civilsamhällesaktörer som arbetar för jämställdhet. Progressiva trosbaserade rörelser som syftar till att främja en teologi som förespråkar genusrättvisa och jämställhet behöver stöd, speciellt på grund av det växande motståndet mot jämställdhet bland annat från trosbaserade aktörer, samt det krympande utrymmet för det civila samhället.

The intervention refers to a 44 MSEK program support to ACT Alliance's Global Gender Justice Programme 2019-2023, through the Strategy for Sweden’s development cooperation for global gender equality and women’s and girls’ rights 2018–2022. The total budget for the programme is 4 525 110 USD.
ACT Alliance is a faith based organization (FBO), representing the world´s largest network of Protestant and Orthodox churches and agencies. The ACT Church of Sweden is a member with an active role in this intervention. Overall ACT Alliance's members are associated with the World Council of Churches or the Lutheran World Federation. Around 70% of ACT Alliance's members are national churches or faith-based church-related organisations from the Global South.
ACT Alliance as a faith-based network is in a key position to act in the transformation of gender injustices by bridging the discourse of religion with that of secular and human rights, and by mobilizing faith leaders. By contributing to changed societal norms, policies and practices through this intervention, ACT Alliance will play a part in contributing to the achievement of SDG5, and the overall vision of a world where gender equality and justice are realised as equal enjoyment of human rights, and where people have the power to freely shape societies, faith communities and their own lives.
By 2023, the Programme expects to have contributed to changed policy, practice, narratives and attitudes on gender justice in faith-communities, by positively affecting the commitment of churches and other faith-based organisations within the Alliance, as well as their programming and their advocacy to promote and realise gender justice. This will be achieved by: 1. Enabling and mobilizing ACT Alliance members’ commitment to promote changes in attitudes and structural arrangements towards a more gender just distribution of power 2. Supporting ACT Alliance Forums in shaping and implementing programmatic work that contributes to gender just societies 3. Using its unique position and networks to act as a global progressive force for gender justice, contributing to the SDGs and connecting the national to the regional and global levels 4. Ensuring that the programme providers’ capacity in the programme areas is strengthened, so that the programme providers and their implementing staff are both institutionally and individually more skilled in the area of gender justice.
Sida assesses the network and role of ACT Alliance as a FBO working with development, humanitarian aid and advocating for gender justice as relevant and additional to civil society engaged in transformational work for gender equality. Progressive faith based movements engaged in promoting a positive faith discourse for gender equality need support, especialy in the midst of a growing backlash on gender equality and shrinking space for civil society, including from faith based groups.

tag.narrative: 5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.3 - Avskaffa alla skadliga sedvänjor, såsom barnäktenskap, tidiga äktenskap och tvångsäktenskap samt kvinnlig könsstympning.
5.3 - Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.

title.narrative: Grant Agreement between Sida and Act Alliance
Beslut om insats, ACT Alliance - Global programme on Gender Justice 2019-2023

description.narrative:
In the reporting period (October 2019 - December 2020), the Global Gender Justice Programme focused on building the foundation for its contribution to advancing gender equality and progressed towards the intended outcomes. The programme is multi-layered and participatory amongst the wide ACT membership (more than 135 members throughout the world) and the ACT Secretariat staff. Therefore, in 2019-2020, strong investment was made in the inclusion of the membership in the work of the programme. There has been significant progress towards the expected results via the strengthening of religious actors’ understanding and promotion of gender justice worldwide, despite the Programme’s virtual delivery and cancellation of many international events in 2020. The Programme will continue to adapt and look for synergies in other areas of the ACT Alliance, in the shared work in achieving justice for all, including climate justice, and with other gender equality advocates. With the restrictions of what became a global pandemic, the partner has had close dialogue with Sida. The programme has been adapted and managed to redesign and consolidate the work. The programme also enabled ACT Alliance to speak out loudly as a progressive religious force against increasing gender-based violence and regression on gender equality around the world during the pandemic. Some examples of results per outcome: Outcome 1: The programme contributed to worldwide efforts to highlight the gendered impact of COVID-19 in communities. Working with religious communities and through all aspects of the programmes’ outcome areas, work contributed to diminish the impact of COVID-19 on women, children, and people of diverse gender identities. This resulted inter alia in gender-specific humanitarian responses in two countries. The programme activities amplified the voice of progressive religious efforts for gender justice in international bodies and conferences (Multi-Faith Advisory Council to the United Nations Inter-Agency Task Force on Religion and Sustainable Development, Generation Equality Forum leadership and planning committee, Steering Committee for the United Nations Office on Genocide prevention and the Responsibility to Protect). The programme is enabling a bold, prophetic and progressive voice to address gendered injustices (also contributing to outcome 3). Broad and impactful results in relation to outcome 1 is to be strengthened by each regional gender justice "Community of Practice" that is currently developing a “Roadmap” to implement the localisation of gender justice policies. These roadmaps cover areas such as mapping the status quo of each member, support for gender justice policy development, gender justice capacity-building and theological reflection, advocacy, and overview of activities of members. Outcome 2: No results have yet been reported for this outcome as the country level projects (that constitute the activities for this outcome) were not identified and grants awarded until late 2020. 10 projects at ACT Forum level that are contributing to gender just societies are now being carried out in Argentina, Guatemala, Serbia. Jordan, Palestine, Solomon Islands, Indonesia, Ethiopia, Zimbabwe and Uganda. In these projects, ACT Alliance Forums have integrated gender justice into their collective programming in the humanitarian, sustainable development and advocacy field (especially focusing on thematic priority areas such as SGBV, SRHR, economic justice, transformative masculinities and family law). Furthermore, the Global Gender Justice Programme is actively participating in the ACT Alliance Humanitarian COVID-19 Appeal process, and it decided to fund the gender component of two COVID-19 appeals in Tanzania and Madagascar. Outcome 3: In 2019 and 2020, ACT Alliance maintained a high profile in numerous global gender justice discussions, being actively involved in advocacy for the implementation of global frameworks to promote gender justice. This has resulted in high visibility and appreciation of the role of ACT Alliance as a progressive faith voice in policy dialogues. An example of that is how ACT played a major role as a faith-based organisation at the International Conference on Population and Development - ICPD +25, the Nairobi Summit. The ACT delegation actively engaged in advocacy and networking, including moderation by the ACT General Secretary, for an official event – “Keeping the faith in SRHR”. ACT Alliance engaged with the ICPD 25 process issuing a brief and a number of statements, including one from the Latin American Gender Community of Practice, endorsed by a considerable number of national forums. This resulted in the display of progressive religious leaders’ commitment and contribution to advancing SRHR at the ICPD in Nairobi. It also resulted in the appointment of ACT Alliance to the High-Level Commission to follow-up on ICPD+25. Outcome 4: The baseline of the Global Gender Justice Programme 2019-2023 was completed in October 2020 and identified gaps and opportunities to strengthen and fine-tune the programme to achieve stong impact. The fundaments for delivering towards this outcome has been advanced as the architecture of the Gender Justice Programme was built during 2020, with its advisory structures, the Reference Group, the Communities of Practice and all the thematic Task Groups. There is a growing interest and engagement of members, faith leaders, and other organisations/movements (feminist, human rights, ecumenical, interfaith) in building a progressive theological/faith narrative on gender justice. To enable ACT members to mobilise commitment to promote changes in attitudes and structural arrangements towards a more gender just distribution of power, the baseline suggests to strenthen efforts for capacity building to ACT members. From the feedback collected, ACT Alliance will have the necessary information to build an evidence-based capacity support plan for its membership.
Lessons learned and unexpected results In 2020, a realistic system of monitoring and evaluation for the programme was developed alongside the revised programmatic log frame. This process underlined the novel experience of this programme within the ACT Alliance, which led to lessons learned. For example, a longer start-up phase should have been planned with an earlier baseline. The multi-layered programme built a participatory structure for all who are key to the Programme’ssuccess - the ACT Secretariat staff, advisory groups and Communities of Practice (CoPs) that involve the global diversity of the Alliance. An important gap identified in the baseline assessment for the programme was the need to design a capacity development strategy for the Gender Justice Programme that organises capacity building opportunities for members. The Gender Core Team plans for this work to be rolled out in 2021. The COVID-19 pandemic opened up for more immediate collaboration between the Gender Justice Team and Humanitarian Team of ACT Alliance. This has lead to improved synergies and possibilities to move ahead in the programme's desired achievement of influencing gender responsive humanitarian programming of ACT Alliance. ACT Gender Justice Programme is also contributing towards building a progressive narrative of faith, engaging in challenging sometimes polemic issues considered taboos in many faith spaces. ACT Alliance addresses difficult issues to be discussed from a faith perspective, like LGBTQI+ or Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights. Using a methodology based on respect, these issues are discussed, in a dialogical and participatory way, using the Latin American method of ‘conversatorios’.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
